page.title: 07Shepley Stone.
page.content: On the southern outskirts of Shepley there still survives a local industry, quarrying; some disused but one still working. These are the home of Shepley Stone. The natural colour is a mixture of brown and blue. Where there is a predominence of blue then the stone is more expensive. The more common coloured stone is used for building and is suitable for steps, jambs, wallstone etc. as the crushing strain is 686 tons per square foot. Local buildings built of Shepley stone include Holme Moss Television Station, the steps to Blackburn Public Hall, Cliffe House and many schools. In London it has been used as paving stones for Trafalgar Square and for parade grounds in Buckingham Palace grounds. It has even been used as pickling tanks for chemical works and for gravestones in London cemeteries.
